instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00239: What is 820-00239? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.PPVCCSA_S0_CPU: What is PPVCCSA_S0_CPU? Main power rail for the CPU. If this is missing the machine will act braindead. This is NOT shorted to ground if it has a low resistance â€“ this is a common mistake people make. A chip that requires high power at a low voltage like a CPU or GPU will have a low measured resistance to ground..
definitions.PPVCCIO_S0_CPU: What is PPVCCIO_S0_CPU? PPVCCIO_S0_CPU is a power rail responsible for powering the part of the CPU responsible for communicating with other portions of the machine prior to PPVCORE_S0_CPU being present and must be present before vcore, PPVCCIO_S0_CPU is present when the machine is in an on, RUNNING state. .

threads.title: MacBook Pro (13-inch, 2016) - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No power after liquid damage
threads.message:
Hi. Could you help me, please?
This mac came from a customer that took it to a previous shop and they cleaned the board, and I can't tell for sure where was the liquid corrosion.
There were signs of corrosion near UB300, <CHIP>U7210</CHIP>.
After replacing <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>, <CHIP>U7220</CHIP>, <CHIP>U7210</CHIP>, <CAPACITOR>C7224</CAPACITOR> it started to get 20V and fan spinning. But the CPU is very hot, more than normal just after plugging the cable.
<SIGNAL>CPUCORE_PWM1</SIGNAL> - Pin 1 - 0.47V instead of 2.2V
<SIGNAL>CPUCORE_PWM2</SIGNAL> - Pin1 - 0.47V instead of 2.2V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 13.02V
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> - 1.04V
<SIGNAL>PPVCCGT_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> - 0V
<SIGNAL>PPVCCSA_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> - 1.04V
<SIGNAL>PPVCCIO_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> - 0.95V
<SIGNAL>CPU_ZVM_L</SIGNAL> - 0V

threads.title: MacBook Pro (13-inch, 2016) - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No power after liquid damage
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>  should drop to 0.6V aprox, when board really boots.

You may have knocked off components.
Just in case, try known good BIOS.

threads.title: MacBook Pro (13-inch, 2016) - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No power after liquid damage
threads.message:
Tried 2 other bios chips and firmware.
Inspecting the board doesn't seem to have any missing components.
There is any way to find out why the  <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> is not dropping to 0.6V?

threads.title: MacBook Pro (13-inch, 2016) - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No power after liquid damage
threads.message:
Missing components, or corroded (traces too).
Bad CPU, or accumulated crap underneath CPU, or RAM.
